title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (October 9, 2019).

Boeing's bid to return MAX jets to service has hit a new snag due to heightened European safety concerns about proposed fixes to the plane's flight-control system.

The Fed will soon increase its purchases of short-term Treasurys to avoid a recurrence of the unexpected strains experienced in money markets last month, Powell said.

J&J was ordered by a jury to pay $8 billion in damages in a case over Risperdal, the latest in a series of legal setbacks for the company.

The NBA's standoff with China escalated in the wake of a team executive's tweet expressing support for protesters in Hong Kong.

Nissan named Makoto Uchida, the head of its China business, as CEO and said the auto maker would be led by a three-person team.

U.S. stocks fell after a flare-up in tensions between the U.S. and China. The Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq lost 1.2%, 1.6% and 1.7%, respectively.

Lions Gate is considering splitting off its Starz premium-cable channel into a separate company as the studio looks to cut its debt.

PG&E is planning to shut off power to hundreds of thousands of people in California starting Wednesday as it seeks to reduce wildfire risks.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 09, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
